34
it can be seen that network stations use more live
material than do the independents. The propor¬
tions of time in live entertainment programs range
from 13.9 per cent for WATV to 75.2 per cent for
WNBT, as shown in Table 22. For a specific
class of entertainment, drama. Table 22 shows that
some stations have little live drama programming
(WATV and WPIX have none at all), while one
station, WNBT, has as much as 40 per cent of its
drama programs in live form.
The proportion of information type programs in
live form is shown to be high for all stations by
Table 24, ranging from 63.9 per cent for WPIX
to 100 per cent for WOR-TV. Orientation pro¬
grams, on the other hand, more frequently are
found in recorded form, as shown by Table 25.
Three of the seven stations have less than half
of their orientation programs in live form, with
WOR-TV having least of all with 29.1 per cent.
However, one station, WABD, did have all of its
orientation programming reported as live by the
monitors in 1954.
